title.narrative: Support for the River Transportation Project In South Sudan

description.narrative:
South Sudan’s economy and ability to respond to the ongoing humanitarian situation is heavily constrained by the sheer absence of a reliable transport system. Air transportation of humanitarian aid is extremely expensive, existing key roads (mostly earth roads) transport supply routes are only accessible during the dry season while the river/water transport sector is underdeveloped and underutilized. The high cost of transporting humanitarian supplies to areas in need creates an opportunity cost, since many vulnerable households are not reached by humanitarian assistance because a large portion of the funds are used for logistics.
Developing the river infrastructure and transport system could improve access and reduce the cost of transport of food and aid in South Sudan. While used locally for smaller transports, the White Nile River is barely used for larger goods transports. This is because the river is not deep or wide enough for barges to pass in some parts. The lack of port structures also makes unloading goods difficult or impossible – most ports today do not have a jetty. Some of the country’s biggest humanitarian issues are directly linked to, and worsened by its poor infrastructure.
With the objective to improve the capacity of South Sudan to utilize and manage river transportation as one way of ensuring that humanitarian aid reaches vulnerable households, funded by the Government of Japan, UNOPS activities include conducting a technical study on construction of a river barge, developing a design for a suitable river barge for South Sudan, strengthening the local capacity in river barge construction and building a river barge prototype based on technical designs from the technical study.
